statements.name: PROC DISTANCE
statements.description: The DISTANCE procedure computes various measures of distance, dissimilarity, or similarity between the observations (rows) of a SAS data set. These proximity measures are stored as a lower triangular matrix or a square matrix in an output data set (depending on the SHAPE= option) that can then be used as input to the CLUSTER, MDS, and MODECLUS procedures. The input data set might contain numeric or character variables, or both, depending on which proximity measure is used.

arguments.name: ABSENT=
arguments.description: Specifies the value to be used as an absence value in an irrelevant absent-absent match for all of the asymmetric nominal variables.

arguments.name: ADD=
arguments.description: Specifies a constant, c, to add to each value after standardizing and multiplying by the value you specify in the MULT= option. The default value is 0.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Specifies the input data set containing observations from which the proximity is computed.

arguments.name: FUZZ=
arguments.description: Specifies the relative fuzz factor for computing the standardized scores. The default value is 1E–14.

arguments.name: INITIAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the method of computing initial estimates for the A-estimates (ABW, AWAVE, and AHUBER). The following methods are not allowed for the INITIAL= option: ABW, AHUBER, AWAVE, and IN.

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: Specifies the method of computing proximity measures.
arguments.help: METHOD=GOWER | DGOWER | EUCLID | SQEUCLID | SIZE | SHAPE | COV | CORR | DCORR | SQCORR | DSQCORR | L(p) | CITYBLOCK | CHEBYCHEV | POWER(p,r) | SIMRATIO | DISRATIO | NONMETRIC | CANBERRA | COSINE | DOT | OVERLAP | DOVERLAP | CHISQ | CHI | PHISQ | PHI | HAMMING | MATCH | dMATCH | DSQMATCH | HAMANN | RT | SS1 | SS3 | DICE | RR | BLWNM | K1 | JACCARD | DJACCARD

arguments.name: GOWER
arguments.description: [Accepts all measurement levels] Gower’s similarity

arguments.name: DGOWER
arguments.description: [Accepts all measurement levels] 1 minus GOWER

arguments.name: EUCLID
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Euclidean distance

arguments.name: SQEUCLID
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Squared Euclidean distance

arguments.name: SIZE
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Size distance

arguments.name: SHAPE
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Shape distance

arguments.name: COV
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Covariance

arguments.name: CORR
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Correlation

arguments.name: DCORR
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Correlation transformed to Euclidean distance

arguments.name: SQCORR
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Squared correlation

arguments.name: DSQCORR
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] One minus squared correlation

arguments.name: L
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Minkowski (Lp) distance, where p is a positive numeric value

arguments.name: CITYBLOCK
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] L1, city-block, or Manhattan distance

arguments.name: CHEBYCHEV
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] L(infinity)

arguments.name: POWER
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Generalized Euclidean distance where p is a positive numeric value and r is a nonnegative numeric value.

arguments.name: SIMRATIO
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio variables] Similarity ratio (if variables are binary, this is the Jaccard coefficient)

arguments.name: DISRATIO
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio variables] One minus similarity ratio

arguments.name: NONMETRIC
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio variables] Lance and Williams nonmetric coefficient

arguments.name: CANBERRA
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio variables] Canberra metric distance coefficient

arguments.name: COSINE
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio variables] Cosine coefficient

arguments.name: DOT
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio variables] Dot (inner) product coefficient

arguments.name: OVERLAP
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio variables] Overlap similarity

arguments.name: DOVERLAP
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio variables] Overlap dissimilarity

arguments.name: CHISQ
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio variables] Chi-square coefficient

arguments.name: CHI
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio variables] Square root of chi-square coefficient

arguments.name: PHISQ
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio variables] Φ² coefficient

arguments.name: PHI
arguments.description: [Accepts ratio variables] Square root of Φ² coefficient

arguments.name: HAMMING
arguments.description: [Accepts nominal variables] Hamming distance

arguments.name: MATCH
arguments.description: [Accepts nominal variables] Simple matching coefficient

arguments.name: dMATCH
arguments.description: [Accepts nominal variables] Simple matching coefficient transformed to Euclidean distance

arguments.name: DSQMATCH
arguments.description: [Accepts nominal variables] Simple matching coefficient transformed to squared Euclidean distance

arguments.name: HAMANN
arguments.description: [Accepts nominal variables] Hamann coefficient

arguments.name: RT
arguments.description: [Accepts nominal variables] Roger and Tanimoto

arguments.name: SS1
arguments.description: [Accepts nominal variables] Sokal and Sneath 1

arguments.name: SS3
arguments.description: [Accepts nominal variables]Sokal and Sneath 3

arguments.name: DICE
arguments.description: [Accepts asymmetric nominal variables] Dice coefficient or Czekanowski/Sorensen similarity coefficient

arguments.name: RR
arguments.description: [Accepts asymmetric nominal variables] Russell and Rao

arguments.name: BLWNM
arguments.description: [Accepts asymmetric nominal variables] Binary Lance and Williams nonmetric, or Bray-Curtis coefficient

arguments.name: K1
arguments.description: [Accepts asymmetric nominal variables] Kulcynski 1

arguments.name: JACCARD
arguments.description: [Accepts asymmetric nominal and ratio variables] Jaccard similarity coefficient

arguments.name: DJACCARD
arguments.description: [Accepts asymmetric nominal and ratio variables] Jaccard dissimilarity coefficient

arguments.name: MULT=
arguments.description: Specifies a numeric constant, c, by which to multiply each value after standardizing. The default value is 1.

arguments.name: NOMISS
arguments.description: Omits observations with missing values from computation of the location and scale measures when standardizing; generates undefined (missing) distances for observations with missing values when computing distances.

arguments.name: NORM
arguments.description: Normalizes the scale estimator to be consistent for the standard deviation of a normal distribution when you specify the option STD=AGK, STD=IQR, STD=MAD, or STD=SPACING in the VAR statement.

arguments.name: NOSTD
arguments.description: Suppresses standardization of the variables. The NOSTD option should not be specified with the STDONLY option or with the REPLACE option.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of the SAS data set created by PROC DISTANCE.

arguments.name: OUTSDZ=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of the SAS data set containing the standardized scores.

arguments.name: PREFIX=
arguments.description: Specifies a prefix for naming the distance variables in the OUT= data set. By default, the names are Dist1, Dist2, ..., Dist. If you specify PREFIX=ABC, the variables are named ABC1, ABC2, ..., ABCn.

arguments.name: RANKSCORE=
arguments.description: Specifies the method of assigning scores to ordinal variables.

arguments.name: MIDRANK
arguments.description: Assigns consecutive integers to each category with consideration of the frequency value. This is the default method.

arguments.name: INDEX
arguments.description: Assigns consecutive integers to each category regardless of frequencies.

arguments.name: REPLACE
arguments.description: Replaces missing data with zero in the standardized data (to correspond to the location measure before standardizing).

arguments.name: REPONLY
arguments.description: Replaces missing data with the location measure specified by the MISSING= option or the STD= option (if the MISSING= option is not specified), but does not standardize the data.

arguments.name: SHAPE=
arguments.description: Specifies the shape of the proximity matrix to be stored in the OUT= data set.

arguments.name: TRIANGLE
arguments.description: SHAPE=TRIANGLE requests the matrix to be stored as a lower triangular matrix.

arguments.name: SQUARE
arguments.description: SHAPE=SQUARE requests that the matrix be stored as a squared matrix.

arguments.name: SNORM
arguments.description: Normalizes the scale estimator to have an expectation of approximately 1 for a standard normal distribution when the STD=SPACING option is specified.

arguments.name: STDONLY
arguments.description: Standardizes variables only and computes no distance matrix. You must use the OUTSDZ= option to save the standardized scores. You cannot specify both the STDONLY option and the NOSTD option.

arguments.name: UNDEF=
arguments.description: Specifies the numeric constant used to replace undefined distances, such as when an observation has all missing values, or if a divisor is zero.

arguments.name: VARDEF=
arguments.description: Specifies the divisor to be used in the calculation of distance, dissimilarity, or similarity measures, and for standardizing variables whenever a variance or covariance is computed.

arguments.name: DF
arguments.description: Degrees of freedom

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Number of observations

arguments.name: WDF
arguments.description: Sum of weights minus

arguments.name: WEIGHT
arguments.description: Sum of weights

statements.name: BY
statements.description: Obtains separate analyses on observations in groups defined by the BY variables.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

statements.name: COPY
statements.description: The COPY statement specifies a list of additional variables to be copied to the OUT= data set.

statements.name: FREQ
statements.description: The frequency variable is used for either standardizing variables or assigning rank scores to the ordinal variables. It has no direct effect on computing the distances.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: The ID statement specifies a single variable to be copied to the OUT= data set and used to generate names for the distance variables. The ID variable must be character.

statements.name: VAR
statements.description: where the syntax for the opt-list is as follows: ABSENT=value MISSING=miss-method | value ORDER=order-option STD=std-method WEIGHTS=weight-list The VAR statement lists variables from which distances are to be computed. The VAR statement is required. The variables can be numeric or character depending on their measurement levels. A variable cannot appear more than once in either the same list or a different list.

arguments.name: ABSENT=
arguments.description: Specifies the value to be used as an absence value in an irrelevant absent-absent match for asymmetric nominal variables.

arguments.name: ANOMINAL
arguments.description: [level value] Variables are asymmetric nominal and can be either numeric or character.

arguments.name: INTERVAL
arguments.description: [level value] Variables are interval and numeric.

arguments.name: MISSING=
arguments.description: Specifies the method (or numeric value) with which to replace missing data.]

arguments.name: NOMINAL
arguments.description: [level value] Variables are symmetric nominal and can be either numeric or character.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: Selects the order for assigning scores to ordinal variables. ]

arguments.name: ASCENDING
arguments.description: Scores are assigned in lowest-to-highest order of unformatted values. This is the default.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Scores are assigned in highest-to-lowest order of unformatted values.

arguments.name: ASCFORMATTED
arguments.description: Scores are assigned in ascending order by their formatted values.

arguments.name: DESFORMATTED
arguments.description: Scores are assigned in descending order by their formatted values.

arguments.name: DSORDER
arguments.description: Scores are assigned according to the order of their appearance in the input data set.

arguments.name: ORDINAL
arguments.description: [level value] Variables are ordinal and can be either numeric or character.

arguments.name: RATIO
arguments.description: [level value] Variables are ratio and numeric. Ratio variables should always contain positive measurements.

arguments.name: STD=
arguments.description: Selects the standardization method.
arguments.help: STD=MEAN | MEDIAN | SUM | EUCLEN | USTD | STD | RANGE | MIDRANGE | MAXABS | IQR | MAD | AWB(c) | AHUBER(c) | AWAVE(c) | AGK(p) | SPACING(p) | L(p)

arguments.name: MEAN
arguments.description: Mean

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Median

arguments.name: SUM
arguments.description: Sum

arguments.name: EUCLEN
arguments.description: Euclidian

arguments.name: USTD
arguments.description: Standard deviation about origin

arguments.name: STD
arguments.description: Standard deviation

arguments.name: RANGE
arguments.description: Range

arguments.name: MIDRANGE
arguments.description: Range/2

arguments.name: MAXABS
arguments.description: Maximum absolute value

arguments.name: IQR
arguments.description: Interval quartile range

arguments.name: MAD
arguments.description: Median absolute deviation from median

arguments.name: AWB
arguments.description: Biweight A-estimate

arguments.name: AHUBER
arguments.description: Huber A-estimate

arguments.name: AWAVE
arguments.description: Wave A-estimate

arguments.name: AGK
arguments.description: AGK estimate (ACECLUS)

arguments.name: SPACING
arguments.description: minimum spacing

arguments.name: L
arguments.description: Lp

arguments.name: WEIGHTS=
arguments.description: Assigns weights to the variables in the list.

statements.name: WEIGHT
statements.description: The WEIGHT statement specifies a numeric variable in the input data set with values that are used to weight each observation. This weight variable is used for standardizing variables rather than computing the distances. Only one variable can be specified.
